author: {'steamid': '76561198016767042', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 5774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3508, 'last_played': 1547236044}
review: Все очень достойно. В целом приятная убивалка времени развивающая кукушку. Если начать придираться, то хотелось бы усложнить экономическую часть, так как покупая все самое дорогое, и делая,не особо вникая, маршруты, все равно улететь в "минус" проблематично. Так же не совсем адекватный AI. Пассажир "выбирает" для себя подходящий маршрут и жестко к нему привязывается. То есть пассажир не умеет подъехать пару остановок на первом попавшемся транспорте, он будет ждать свой избарнный. Но судя по всему исправлений AI в этой игре не будет больше. Хотя меня и так устраивает.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995866136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1854, 'last_played': 1456642287}
review:
Cities in Motion 2 is much more in depth than the original game, which results in a slightly higher learning curve.  The gameplay itself is fun, as you build a mass transit system for a small town or large city.  Making the trains run on time, setting prices, and satisfying your customers all makes for a fun game.

However, there are a host of bugs that I've experienced that decrease my experience in the game, specifically with additional content downloaded from the Steam workshop.  The Steam workshop is great, with alot of new maps and add-ons making the game so much better.  Unfortunately the maps tend to get buggy at times, resulting in corrupted save games, with hours of work lost.

Nevertheless, the stock game itself is good, and I still recommend this game, especially if you are a fan of the SimCity series, or the original Cities in Motion, or even Tycoon games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963774443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 9446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7953, 'last_played': 1553460979}
review:
The tutorial in this game is useless, since there's a ton of little annoying things that are not intuitive. But once you know, it works: 

You have to delete and rebuild roads to get bus lanes. Trams can have tracks on medians and pedestrian paths, and you have to build the tram station appropriately (in the median or on the side of the road). Metros can be built elevated or underground with the page up/page down key (minimum clearance is 8m, which is two page ups/page downs). Building metro track at elevation zero (0 m) will enable your cursor to snap to metro track stubs. Building a metro track/road curve is like using the pen tool in photoshop: you drop a vertex with left click and you undo the last vertex with right click. Waterbuses cannot navigate through/around terrain, so you have to manually waypoint around those. The metro passenger entry point is that tiny "teleportation box" that appears on the nearest roadway when you build the station. Tram tracks/Trolley Wires need to be connected through intersections by clicking on the tracks/wires on one side, then clicking on the side you want to connect to. If there's no routable path to the next station, zoom in and inspect the roads for one-way streets and missing intersections. When you delete intersecting roads/metro tracks, the remaining road can still have remnants of an "intersection" that makes it count as two roads. That "intersection" can be deleted again to turn the road back into a single piece of road/track.

If you do play multiplayer, PAUSE THE GAME OR SLOW IT DOWN BEFORE DEMOLISHING ANYTHING, and try not to demolish a lot of things in rapid succession. Don't play it on the fastest speed. If you do desync, have one person share their save file with everyone else and overwrite their local saves, then try to rehost the game.

You can adjust the rulesets to do things like make the game speed slower (helpful for big, lagtacular maps) and increase depot size (recommended).

Hopefully reading this makes the game playable, since it's pretty fun once you know all the little things. But then again, I was determined to make it work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041863959', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1260, 'last_played': 1417162953}
review: Um bom simulador para quem curte o gênero. Simples e complicado ao mesmo tempo. Simples por focar apenas na gerência de sistemas de transporte, e complicado pelas mudanças que acontecem na cidade. A forma de jogar pode parecer complicada no ínicio, mas basta poucas  horas para se pegar o jeito e começar a brincar pra valer. O modo singleplayer consiste por missões impostas por diversos cidadãos que te fazem elevar o nível de reputação. Não há concorrência no singleplayer, se você gosta de disputar melhor se aventurar no multiplayer, isso se você conseguir achar alguma sala...

author: {'steamid': '76561198036353055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1365404400}
review:
This game could be good, but unfortunately isn't. There are so many bugs, stupid pathfinding, impractical UI - and authors resigned to do anything but new graphics DLC. So you can buy vehicle DLC containing five new vehicles, but these vehicles will be stuck at empty road without any reason (that's only one of many bugs).
Authors resigned to improve UI, to fix bugs, and even to communicate with community. If you write "That's lovely new vehicle", they write "Thank you :)", but if you write "Are you planning to fix the bugs?", they write nothing. And i personally hate this approach to customers. So no - don't buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080891651', 'num_games_owned': 95, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3699, 'last_played': 1582929078}
review:
C'est pas mal. On a une capacité à gérer un peu mieux la configuration de notre ville, le rôle passe au-delà de la gestion de nos transports en nous laissant modifier les axes de transports. 

Je trouve par contre dommage que l'idée de temps se limite aux semaines et pas aux années. J'avais beaucoup apprécié les changements d'années et des différentes générations de bus, trams... Autre point négatif, le mode multi-joueurs ne marche pas! C'est dommage, cela aurait été intéressant de voir ce que ça donne... 

Mais bon, le jeu reste intéressant! 

Contenu DLC intérresssant, pour les métros, ça aurait été bien de pouvoir faire fonctionner les métros de base avec les autres... 

Pour un troisième opus, une combinaison des 2 premiers?

author: {'steamid': '76561197969202898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1399038397}
review:
Bug ridden, inconsistent. Big disappointment and waste of money - cannot recommend.
Some problems:
* making a line with more than 10/20 cars is nearly impossible, adding multiple depots gives frequent 'cannot route' errors
* cars break down too easily, and the above problem leads to micromanagement to add/remove cars
* sometimes metro tracks are laid down without actual tracks - no warning is given, restarting a track is cumbersome
* notifications cannot be disabled
* windows overflow the screen, hiding the interface does not help
Expectations:
* allow control of notifications and vehicle wear (disable that 'feature', or at least increase the time for the vehicle to break down)
* prevent micro management, e.g.: auto -vehicle management / no broken vehicles
* filtering notifications
* consistent control and routing
* allow mass-closing of (unneeded) windows

review:
Beware of the retarded metro system that will force you to spend all your money on some useless rails that wont connect to eachother.

You end up in a giant debt that will force you to start over again and again.


Now when you have abandoned the idea of having a metro system you discover that barely noone wants to ride your awesome transportation system and yet again this will put you in an economical disaster.

Some woman will eventually promise you some dosh if you put up a line between given positions, DO NOT trust that skank.
You wont recieve any money and only like 2 ppl a day will ride it.
It is like 50% chance that you get paid.


It could be kind of fun when you have learned to save before building that damn metro that will cost you everything you have and a little more, then you could do it for as many times that's nescessary to get this shit together, probably around 8 attempts will do.

Love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074486631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1397878242}
review: Cities in Motion 2 is a great instalment in transportation simulators. The game is very simple and is, though sometimes tedious, very fun. Once you set your transportation empire going the sky is the limit. You can make routes for several public transport vehicles. You can make a bus line (good for short distances). You can make a trolley (looks cool). You can also, my favourite, make a tram line (very simple and fun). There are also metro and waterbus lines, these are very complicated and take a lot of logistics to maintain and plot. Great game and I highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197965660479', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 5594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1541429610}
review: The original Cities in Motion was already a great cousin to business sims like the legendary Transport Tycoon, but the sequel really kicks it up a notch. Since you can build roads SimCity style, it now feels more like a city simulator restricted to running the department of transportation than a straight-up business simulation. It has a lot more depth (like the timetables and depots), but it doesn't take long to get the hang of what's new. If you enjoy business simulations, this is a must-have for your collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971590747', 'num_games_owned': 427, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1494482420}
review: It is one of those games that specialises for a niche market instead of trying to be some generic AAA title. Does the idea of building tram/metro lines, placing stops, setting up lines and fine tuning timetables sound fun to you? No? Then you will not enjoy cities in motion. That is fine. However if you love that kind of micro management, monitoring how well your transport network is doing with charts and looking forward to your next optimised transport route then this game will keep you up all night!

author: {'steamid': '76561198064156757', 'num_games_owned': 3338, 'num_reviews': 380, 'playtime_forever': 52167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38779, 'last_played': 1664586283}
review:
Cities in Motion 2 is the sequel to the popular mass transit simulation game Cities in Motion. Build, manage and lead your transportation network to provide cities with their ever changing needs. CIM2 introduces new features including multiplayer game modes, day and night cycles, timetables and dynamic cities. 

Building the transportation network will directly affect how the city grows. Affordable transportation brings middle class housing and work places, while more expensive and exotic choices bring high end businesses. Take advantage of many different types of vehicles including buses, trams, ferries and more. 

Build alone or play cooperatively with a friend. Use the newly implemented bus lanes to build efficient traffic free roadways. Tackle rush hour by managing transportation timetables and meeting the needs of the citizens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003589581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 6236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2096, 'last_played': 1704881707}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990903830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1604724796}
review:
What happened. The original Cities in Motion is one of my all time favorite games. This one looks great, but once you get to playing the game, it is a total pain in the ass! Who came up with this UI?!? You think a little carryover in the controls and interface would happen. NOTHING. CiM2 has been re-enginerred to be 300% less efficent* in accessing important game features. Why WOULD YOU MAKE THE BUTTON THAT USED TO OPEN THE CONSTRUCTION MENU COMPLETELY CHANGE YOUR POSITION ON THE MAP! WHY DID YOU DO THIS. And its not just carrying over controls. This is the least intutive menu system I have ever worked with. If you don't do things in an exact order, it is punitive in making you go through another menu system instead of having the oft used function right next to it.

Sorry guys. I loved the orginal, but you all royally messed up the controls and mechanics of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037172554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2005, 'last_played': 1702236422}
review:
Grafik: 4/5 Pkt.
Sehr schöne Grafik. Leider sind die kleinen engen Gassen aus CiM1 nichtmehr dabei.
Alles im New-York-City Stil leider.
Inhalt: 2/5 Pkt.
+Kaum mehr Störungen durch Depots
+Fahrplan selbst erstellen
-Story schwer spielbar.
-Wird schnell langweilig, nicht wie Teil 1.
Singleplayer: 2/5 Pkt.
Die Kampagne ist komisch. 30% Netzabdeckung erreichen z.B. nach vielen Linien hat man immer noch 0%
Multiplayer: 2/5 Pkt.
Netter Ansatz aber kaum Aktivität
Story: 3/5 Pkt.
Spaßfaktor: 3/5 Pkt.
wird schneller langweilig als CiM1. Verkehr ist sehr schön simuliert.
Viele Staus mal wieder.



Gesamt: 16/30

author: {'steamid': '76561198047641680', 'num_games_owned': 591, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1424879429}
review:
Into a city-simulation mode atm. Seshed the hell out of Cities XL yesterday, and installed this today.. Dubious after reading negative reviews, I went ahead as it has a worthwhile metascore rating..

Safe to say these reviews are correct.. Its not fully in depth to get your hands around with on a starter tutorial.
Thrown in making a bus station, and have to create a route, and repeat on a tram depot.. But, it doesnt give you a lowdown of "hey this is how u correctly apply bus/tram stops, tram tracks & create a line" - after ten mins trying to understand the tram, I gave up.. Back to cities XL, FAR more enjoyable. Spend your money on that instead- and From what I see no DLC, just free mods.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000537934', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4278, 'last_played': 1437686105}
review:
I guess it's easy to hate on SimCity with this review. We can go on all day about how shit that game was, but that'd be praising Cities In Motion 2 on the account of it's main competitor being ****. I won't do that. Instead, I'll relate to another game. One that has a lot more love.

I will relate this game to Transport Tycoon. Because this game is much more similar to that game in many respects.

Like TT, Cities In Motion is a game about building transport systems. The scale is limited to a large city rather than a large land, and the cargo variety is minimized to just passengers, but for the rest, it's very much like TT. And that's kind of that.

Beyond that, CiM2 has a lot of different stuff. You build stops and direct bus lines through them. One bus line may not yield much. But when that line links up to a different line, not necessarily a bus line, people along the second line will use the first line too if they need to go there. Passengers go places and your transport systems are there to help that be possible without needing to pick up a car.

The roadbuilding is very free-form. Just click a point, and then another, and it'll connect them with a straight line. Click a third point, and it'll create a nice curve. Keep clicking new points and you have a scribble. Or a long line. Or a long curve. Click the last point and the road is built. It's very simple.

However, this game has some problems of it's own. Let's start off with the biggest problem: stability. The game runs on Unity. And while Unity is pretty good at making decent games, it does suffer from a minor stability issue, where the game crashes due to a GetThreadContextException. If you save a lot, the game will remain manageable, and the progress loss will be minor, but it is a nuisance that is common in Unity games.

The UI may require a little direction, but is manageable once you've completed the tutorial. The tutorial does miss a few mechanics, though. For instance, you'll need to go to Reddit or the wiki to find out how to work with water buses and trolleys, although the latter is similar to the trams in many ways.

Then there's some missing features which'll leave most players going WTF MATES?! One thing I miss is the ability to change roads without having to demolish them.

Next, there's difficulty. While metros are a massive investment, if you get major corners of a city connected, you'll earn it all back in a single afternoon. In the days that follow, you spend most of your time getting rid of the passenger back-ups that are caused by the vast new amount of transport opportunities. And while you'd expect 50% coverage is an easy feat, it's surprisingly difficult. But with no competition and the lack of a loss condition, there is limited challenge.

The last complaint I have is the fact that at the moment (2014-03-23) I think some of the DLC has a fairly poor content/value balance. Furthermore, there's multiple packages that are very focused on owners of the older Cities In Motion. Despite that, some DLC does offer some nice changes. For instance, the Metro DLC completely overhauls the mechanics of the Metros, making the whole system a lot deeper. Fortunately, there is no vital DLC. The game is perfectly playable without any DLC. I do believe that the DLC offers a lot of options that are better than the standard options though.

Despite that, it has some nice things. For one, the world looks very good. I find it very relaxing to for instance just position my camera over a suburban surface railway station and just watch the trains come and go. Also, the passenger simulation has a great, but manageable level of detail. It quickly becomes noticeable if that multi-million dollar metro line was really worth covering the entire city for, but passengers use it and existing lines that barely made the cut have now become viable, so it probably is. You can get a lot of information about the state of your city and your company by looking at the data views, and some of that information can tell you very useful stuff, like if it's a good idea to use the highway, or to build a dedicated route, as well as if a line is likely to provide your system with a good amount of traffic.

On the whole, I think this is a good game. It has it's flaws, yes, like relatively high DLC prices, roads being impossible to upgrade without having to tear them down, and some other minor nuisances. But it's good looking, plays fairly well, and if you're a perfectionist and immense fan of making a perfect transport system, this'll keep you busy for hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990523893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 271, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1395325958}
review:
Pretty horrible. I was thinking some Simcity style games but instead its a transportation simulator. Thats what happens when you buy humble bundles. You get crap you never really wanted but looked neat.

That said this game has an absolutely terrible UI, is difficult to control, and is about as fun as you would expect a govt transport designers job would be and you cant even have a web of intrigue and corruption that every govt official loves to have.

Don't get it unless you like the prospect of watching paint dry while humping a door knob.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064982527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1546, 'last_played': 1515588549}
review: Great game, a vast improvement on previous game. You can build ferry, metro, tram, trooley bus and bus lines to connect your city while managing your transport system to cater for rush hours (eg: put on more trains or larger capacity veichals per route) also as it is workshop connected you get loads of great free cities. One other point is that you can build your own cities and download cities with railways etc already built so you just have to put in stops and routes and just manage your system. The only problem is sometimes you have to load it a couple of times for the water to load

author: {'steamid': '76561198040659457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1411315140}
review:
El juego mejora en varios aspectos la primera parte. Más control por parte del jugador: desde fijar horarios hasta asignar los autobuses a cada una de las franjas horarias. Más realista: ahora debemos tener depósitos de autobuses/tranvías, no salen de la nada. Más lógico: puedes autorizar que los autobuses vayan un poco más llenos con gente de pie (la limitación de plazas hacía de Cities in Motion una locura en ciudades medianas y grandes)
Como puntos negativos, no está en castellano (aunque con un nivel medio de inglés es jugable), sigue sin haber rotondas (raro dado que el juego está hecho por un estudio europeo) y el sistema de precio de los billetes es sumamente caprichoso (pudiendo pasar de barato para los usuarios a carísimo de un día a otro).
Totalmente recomendado para los que disfrutaron de la primera entrega pero se quedaron con ganas de más control.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025474172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1395893036}
review:
This is a difficult game to learn. Some of my skills transferred over from CIM1, but I still had to watch a youtube video to figure out how to get a metro going. But the reward is pretty good. Going full 3d is a nice improvment over CIM1, as well as the ability to build roads and expressways. The city feels even more real. although I have yet to turn a profit. 

I love it, but it's definitely hard to get into. You need the gene that thinks model trains are cool.

review: Clunky, quirky, and fiddley, I think most people would struggle to find the fun in this game. But if you belong to that niche market who really likes designing transport systems complete with scheduling and pricing, then maybe you are prepared to get used to the interface and the games functionality, and perhaps you will also be prepared to dig deeper than me and find some deeply buried treasure here. Though I certainly have failed to find any so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969714752', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2042, 'last_played': 1400452245}
review: Ahh so much potential. So many bugs. Let me start by saying this is a game that would get a solid 8/10 if the developers had spent just a few more days polishing this off.  Want to scroll around the map with the mouse? Too bad. Like a useful tutorial? Nien. Want to connect two metro lines together? Fúck you. Made a mistake about 50k$ ago designing that highway? No Undo. Time to load that save from a million years ago. When Chris Saywer made the ambrosia that is RollerCoaster Tycoon, he understood that you wanted to design a path - AND THEN pay for it. This was figured out in 1999 guys. Scenario goals not working? Let's check google; oh hey some people had the same problem six months ago. No patch, just more shít DLC. Here is the secret to winning for those interested: take out a huge loan and build one really good metro right at the start. Now leave your game on overnight and you can come back and have fun when you have actual cashflow. Cities in Motion 2 is a great sandbox game ruined by seemingly arbitrary design decisions at Paradox Interactive. 5/10 for a nice-looking game that doesn't deliver.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024190148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1386719671}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063453613', 'num_games_owned': 254, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1399213684}
review:

Dieses Game ist einfach Klasse und sollte ein Oskar gewinnen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198110467110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8266, 'last_played': 1394912809}
review: É extremamente exaustivo vencer a campanha e alcançar todas as conquistas, algumas são muitas fáceis, outras definitivamente difíceis. O jogo é cansativo em algumas horas, mas vale a pena! É bastante complexo, com muitas informações personalizáveis para cada linha, depósito, veículos, parada e etc. É uma pena, porém, que o desenvolvedor tenha disponibilizado a grande parte dos veiculos em DLC's, isto é, para ter um bom proveito do game, é preciso comprar praticamente todos os DLC's já que a proposta do jogo é justamente viabilizar o transporte público nas cidades. Os gráficos são muito bacanas! A quantidade de detalhes é imensurável! Só restou ter um mutiplayer mais ativo, porque está praticamente morto! É quase impossível encontrar alguém online para disputar uma partida! É mais fácil hospedar uma e aguardar longas horas para algum russo, alemão, japonês, conectar em sua partida.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063662447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1432499740}
review:
По сравнению с первой частью провал.
Графика как бы стала лучше, но мне режет глаза, не хватает сглаживания, трудно ориентироватся.
Ввели много новых фич по типу- Возможность создания тарифных зон, строительство дорог, более расширенную экономику.
Но в остальном бред. Сделали эти депо,  с ними теперь гемор. Испоганили интерфейс, теперь он по стилю- Модерн, но на деле ужас какой не удобный, все самое необходимое приходится выискивать, а а функции, которые используешь, даст бог 2-3 раза за игру на самом видном месте. В общем я разочарован. DLC с техникой из 1 части, разработчики в конец обленились и просто штампуют ккал для извлечения прибыли. 5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046245362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1292, 'last_played': 1566840680}
review: Великолепное исполнение, в отличии от первой части эта намного стабильнее, и игра не виснет при строительстве более 15 линий. Самый главный плюс это постановка расписаний общественного транспорта. Управление очень простое и удобное. В игре много реализма, нужно рассчитывать  расписание так что бы транспорт успевал проходить технический осмотр, иначе будут поломки, задержки на линиях если это метро или трамвай. Забавным элементом мне показалась фишка при закупки излишнего транспорта в депо, опять же если не рассчитать время будут заторы у депо. Единственным минусом считаю скудное количество транспорта, даже со всеми дополнениями. В общем рекомендую данную игру каждому заядлому стратегу.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077033293', 'num_games_owned': 740, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1407064956}
review:
Note: This is a review intended for people with the disability called age. Particularly Hyperopia, near-sightedness, the need for reading glasses (almost everyone over the age of 40)

This game is unplayable. Period. I can't finish the tutorial because the font is not scalable and is by default extremely tiny and really ugly. The developers seem to be aware of the problem and there are a lot of people complaining about it on various forums, but they have as yet failed to fix the problem. There has been DLC,  there have been patches. And still the game is unplayable. It really is a shame because the first installment was a joy to play. The publishers are missing out because I am a DLC completion idiot. Come on, Paradox, get your whip out and get these developers to fix their game.

review:
필자는 솔직히 호불호가 상당히 갈리는 게임이라고 생각한다.
게임을 이해하지 못하는 사람들은 재미를 느낄 수 없을 것이며, 지루함 역시 동반할 것이다.
게임을 빠르게 이해하고, 약점을 파해친다면, 벌리는 돈에 함박웃음을 짓게 될 것이다.
한마디로 인간의 지능을 테스트 할 수 있는 게임이다.
다른게임과는 다르다. 지능테스트에 자신이 있다면 Cities in motion 2를 구매하길 바란다.

review: A really great game, just make sure to watch tutorials online to learn how to make your lines for your buses, trams, etc. And another thing to keep in mind that it's similar to SimCity, but it won't replace it! This game is possibly more close to how it is like to manage a city from my experience. But, it's not that great of experience... Take my advice and try the game OUT! :) It's cheap and there's a ton of ways to expand the experience such as DLC and what not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076254110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1431227315}
review:
CIM2 is a fantastic game in which you can create an entire transit system, either following scenarios or in sandbox mode.  The game itself is fantastic, and boasts excellent and lively graphics.  The game runs very smoothly for me and has never crashed on me, nor has it lagged badly.  (Although, don't try this on an under-par computer.  It WILL crash then, but it's a high graphic game.  What did you expect?)

All in all, I truly enjoy this game.  It offers a plethora of playing time, as there is no definite end to the game.  I would definitely recommend grabbing it from the store if you have a chance.  It's worth it! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198016949587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8685, 'last_played': 1432941783}
review:
Idea general.

Eres dueño de una empresa de transporte publico y partes con alguna ciudad ya construida (hay algunas muy grandes), entonces debes planear lineas de transporte publico para conectar puntos claves de la ciudad y hacer dinero en el proceso. Tienes disponibles buses, trolebuses (como los de Valpo), tranvias, metro y transbordadores (barcos).

Aqui no movemos carga, solo pasajeros. Sin embargo, hay varios tipos de pasajeros desparramados por la ciudad, con distintas necesidades y preferencias.
Los distintos tipos de pasajeros son:

Turistas.
Estudiantes.
Pensionados (Jubilados).
Obreros (cuellos azules).
Oficinistas (cuellos blancos).
Gente de negocios (Profesionales de clase alta).

Caracteristicas principales:

- Totalmente en 3d con mapas bastante grandes.
- La ciudad es dinamica.
- Ciclos de dia y noche, dias de semana con horas punta y baja demanda, etc.
- Gestion sistema tarifario por zonas, lineas, sueldos de empleados, etc.
- Varias Alternativas de vehiculos disponibles segun el medio de transporte elegido.
- Gestion de horarios de salida.
- Disponible campaña para 1 jugador y sanbox para explorar las muchas posibilidades sin limitarse por el presupuesto.
- Disponible Multijugador cooperativo o competitivo, ¡sin esas mie*** al estilo DRM!.
- Poderoso Editor de mapas con terraformacion y todo.

Lo bueno...

Para empezar, las ciudades que te entregan ya estan hechas, pero son dinamicas, osea que los edificios pueden ir apareciendo o cambiando segun las desiciones del jugador, ademas que puedes ampliarla trazando calles nuevas, con una enorme variedad disponible. Entonces si se dan ciertas condiciones, automaticamente comenzaran a aparecer nuevos edificios o casas cerca del nuevo camino trazado.

Puedo trazar caminos, avenidas, puentes, tuneles, vias elevadas, subterraneas, Vias de metro, autopistas con diversas salidas y combinaciones, pistas exclusivas para buses, etc, etc. En teoria, con el editor de mapas, google earth y la suficiente paciencia, es posible recrear la ciudad que quieras. De hecho vi un video en youtube, donde un tipo superpone el mapa de google earth sobre el mapa del editor y traza una ciudad real a escala 1:1 !!!

El nivel de microgestion es elevado, con mucha info y estadisticas para ver y analizar. La informacion de cada edificio y ciudadano tambien estan disponibles.


Lo malo...

Lejos lo peor es la interfaz del juego. Es monotona, le falta estilo, no es para nada intuitiva y estoba a momentos, muy parecida al "Open TTD", anque logra entregar la informacion que necesitas. Lo mismo es el manejo de camara, que es un tanto torpe y rigida, imposible no contrastarlo con el de Simcity 2013, donde la interfaz es tremendamente intuitiva y la camara se mueve suave y majestuosamente bien. Aca en ocasiones es dificil ver lo que se necesita, sobretodo el modo subterraneo.

Carece de un tutorial decente, la curva de aprendizaje es pronunciada y a no ser que seas un fan de este estilo de juego, puede que te aburra rapido, porque no sabes como hacer las cosas y no hay muchas pistas de como hacerlas. Por ejemplo, al principio, experimente trazando calles nuevas, pero solo lograba trazar calles rectas, sabia que podia hacer calles curvas y con elevacion, pero solo mirando videos de usuarios en youtube, pude descubrir que con un click izquierdo simple, puedes marcar puntos de control y con repag y avpag modificar la altura del camino, pero tube que googlear un rato fuera del juego, para descubrir algo tan simple como eso! (Muy mal).

La cantidad de informacion y estadisticas es abrumadora y no siempre sabes como podrias aprovecharla.
El que te guste o no, dependera del tipo de juego que buscas, en cuanto a mi, me gusto bastante.
Saludos

author: {'steamid': '76561197974468354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1337, 'last_played': 1387149340}
review:
[h1] Tolles Spiel für zwischendurch, aber keine große Herausforderung [/h1]

Ich krame das Spiel ab und zu mal raus, um es zu spielen. Es macht Spass die Linien einzurichten, zusätzliche Strecken zu bauen und zuzusehen, wie sich die Infrastruktur entwickelt. 
Leider ist man irgendwann, ohne U-Bahn, aufgrund des Kundenaufkommens, nicht mehr im Stande der Situation einigermaßen realistisch herr zu werden. 
Zusätzlich kommt durch die hohe Transportquote der U-Bahn sehr schnell sehr viel Geld in die Kasse, was dann das Spiel zu einfach werden lässt. Dadurch verliert es ab diesem Zeitpunkt sehr an Reiz.

Natürlich kann man den Reiz durch eigene Spielregeln erhöhen, aber sicherlich hätte man hier noch ein bisschen Feinschliff reinstecken können. Wahrscheinlich vermisse ich die angenehme Schwere von Verkehrsgigant.

Für Profis sind die 20 € ok, aber nicht zu viel erwarten. Anfänger haben bestimmt ihren Spaß.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110433328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 12044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4854, 'last_played': 1557171017}
review:
Отличная игра про пассажирский транспорт! Фанатам игр OpenTTD и Simutrans рекомендую!
Пользовательский интерфейс и управление в игре не самое лучше, но привыкнуть можно. 
Транспортная модель, расписания, прорисовка деталей, кривые дороги, эстакады - сделано шикарно!

p.s. по началу часто вылетала, в последнее время вроде почти нет. Не знаю, с чем это связано, может что-то исправили.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109883351', 'num_games_owned': 1814, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 4479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4284, 'last_played': 1394988806}
review:
Background: I love city builders and have wanted to try this twist on the genre for quite some time.. and then Humble Bundle comes to the rescue. Have played the base game with none of the expansions.

Impressions: This is such a hard game to give a fair review too.. and it's not that it's a bad game... it just has a  frustrating element to seemingly balance out every good one. 

The biggest issues are with the tutorial poorly describes the two systems it covers and does very little to prepare you for the deep-end when it finishes. To really play with any degree of success it's essential to watch some tutorials videos online and read some fan sites to get information on just how the transport systems work. 

There's so much game play and it's fun to build thriving economies but so frustrating when you cant see why your city is failing or when one poor choice has you scurrying back to the last save you made till you save before placing every single building.

The Good:
*Decent graphics and sound, not amazing but more than adequate.
*Nice touches like seeing individual people travelling around the network.
*A range of transport options that are nicely animated.
*Pre-order bonuses are now free in the inbuilt store.
*Intelligently connecting lines gives satisfying results.
*Growing a city really feels like you are making a difference.
*Creating routes requires some thought and the campaign makes you think more as you progress.
*Campaign is really fun, if disjointed, as you town hop back-n-fore.

The Bad:
*Steep learning curve and terribly inadequate tutorial.
*Graphics and sound don't wow you but aren't irritating either.
*Despite a range of transport several systems feel too much alike.
*Campaign missions are repetitive, boring and lack vital info.
*Ticket pricing and wages are lacking depth.
*Despite dozens of information windows some feedback just isn't available.
*Setting timetables is a chore, even with the copy function.
*Building/Stop upgrading is initially confusing.
*Very limited modding options, which could have been really fun.

Recommended for:
City builders and god game people. Certainly for teenagers as there's little to wow a younger audience.

Conclusion.
7/10. I so badly want to give this an 8/10 but the problems in the base game stop it being as fun as it so nearly was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031877877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 8844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1689055459}
review:
Much more options to build buildings/roads/transportation than the original Cities in Motion! While I still believe there's much more to improve/change in the game controls, most of the issues/limitations I had in the original CiM has been addressed in 2. I don't really have much more to say other than the fact that I LOVE this game and 2 is a HUGE improvement over the original in almost every aspect.

My score: 9/10 

(Note that this is a personal score, and it is not based on some strict analysis or a formula. Depending on the player, you may find managing public transportation as a game to be very boring or frustrating.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197983733611', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1393036743}
review:
Honestly, I don't see the fun in managing the transport needs of a city. But I gave the game a shot as I wanted the trading cards...

I got maybe 4-5 steps into the "tutorial", which wasn't intuative in the least, and just quit. The menus don't seem well laid out and remembering where every little item is makes me feel like I'd need to print out a giant poster of where every option is located under which menu and sub-menu in order to play, and that takes the fun out of a game for me.

I can deal with games like SimCity or CitiesXL where I don't feel like I have no choice but to micromanage in order to play, which is the impression that this game gave me.

Thankfully, I got this in a HumbleBundle, so it's a bit easier to swollow. But at the $20 current price, no, I don't recommend this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009903018', 'num_games_owned': 1296, 'num_reviews': 325, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1376097569}
review:
The game:

- dripping with promises, intriguing, tempting...
- and so poorly executed in some CRUCIAL mechanisms, that one wonders if the developers have ever actually played a management simulation game!

I focus on the main point that make me literally "scream": manage the speed of the game...
Also setting MAX speed, the game is soooooo slow that take ages only to finish a stupid working week...

Oh, ok, I can change it through the settings, right? You mean these incredible and stupid list of about THREE hundred voices?
Ok, can I just set time to be more... "fast"? No problem, but, if you want to change also "how" the world go fast meanwhile, you have to change these other settings... and this other... and find an improbable balance (yeah, I know it's difficult to understand, but this is HOW it actually works the game!).

And so it's practically impossible to change game speed... because, also if you manage to find an "ideal" setting, the game is NOT BEING BUILD to change ANY of these settings and make it work, so you'll find innumerable errors, that make this game look as a business simulation game like a Barbie(TM) game would look like!

And why the city are so small and grow so slowly? Why my commuters return at home (from work) at 11 of evening? Why some bugs don't let me set a normal ferry service?

It's a game that brings many "why"...

But the first, surely is: WHY I have spent 30 euros (game expansion), many restart, and 60 hours of my precious time to play on it, waiting and hoping for the next patch?

author: {'steamid': '76561198026307192', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 19190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16444, 'last_played': 1471863883}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031039906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 11122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2142, 'last_played': 1655966612}
review:
I've played many tycoon games. I like this game and finished the campaign for it. It's not difficult to win once you get a feel for what the different transport types can support and how to space them out to give good service(hint: try following a grid, <5 minutes round trip for any one line). It can be very relaxing, even when you're doing poorly, and there are plenty of options for setting up a complex network even without the DLC additions.

I have two issues with the game:

The first is that track and stop placement can be tedious and error-prone, depending on which type of transit you're working with. Although the majority of the time, you want your tram and trolley lines(which are built at street level) to either continue straight ahead or take a 90-degree bend, you have to carefully click each road segment and scroll each time, which, combined with the low visibility of these constructions, almost guarantees that you mess up and fail to link one of the segments and then have to go back and debug it when the game tells you the route can't reach a stop. There is no tool to simplify this construction phase, even though the game can adequately plan the entire route for you when you use buses on existing roads - so you may spend a LOT of time squinting and clicking. Similarly, when building underground roads or metro lines, there is no way to view through the roads, which means that when you go to add stops, you have to either work extremely hard to position the camera to see through a road, build around the road, or tear up the road and add it again. 

A lazy player is going to want to build only buses, watertaxis and underground metros that consciously avoid overlapping the road.

The second problem is with the city growth model. To induce growth, all a player has to do is build new roads with sidewalks, and improve overall transit service. The player doesn't get any control over what types of zones appear, even though they're relevant to decisions about transit scheduling and peak service. This makes city growth feel very "one size fits all" - the growth is generic so you have to build generically - and since you can add roads anywhere that the terrain will fit, the simplest growth strategy is rinse-and-repeat: build a new metro line, and build roads on top of it. When I discovered this it  detracted from any sense of individual character amongst cities. Growth can be turned off, at the expense of making the game feel more like a static "fill in the blanks" exercise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988530082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1410, 'last_played': 1424537098}
review:
Da ich gerne Verkehrssimulationen spielen, bin ich bei diesem Spiel gut aufgehoben. Man kann einfach und felexibel verschiedene Linien bauen. Besondrs die Freiheit beim U-Bahnbau macht extrem viel Spaß.

Nach längerem spielen habe ich festgestellt, dass die Simulation fast nur vortäuscht. Es ist nicht klar welche Person wo wohnt, wo arbeitet und gerade meine Buslinie verwenden. Das Geldsystem ist seltsam. Man kann große Kredite aufnehmen und selbst nach längerem Spielen werden sie nicht abgezahlt.

Hinzu kommen die Aufträge, bei denen man die Stadt zum wachsen bringen soll. es ist nicht klar wie das gehen soll. Man baut Straßen, es ist aber nicht ersichtlich warum sich manchmal kleine Häuser ansiedeln, manchmal große.

Fazit: Oberflächlich macht es Spaß aber die Simulation in der Tiefe ist nicht ausgereift

author: {'steamid': '76561198096324526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2376, 'last_played': 1567395588}
review: You like transportationh right? You know buses, ferries, trams, trolley buses, and metros right? Would you like to make your own routes in a city? You you like to build your own tracks for your metro? Would you like to see how releastic this game is? Would you like me to stop asking you these questions? Well if you like most of what I asked, this game is definetly for you. I love public transportation, and this game allowed me to make my own methods of transit. Of course, there are some points where you say, "ok I'm bored," but when you get the extra dlcs, you won't stop playing for days! So what are you waiting for? GET YOUR COPY ALREADY!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198075716247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1389734184}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009538861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1211, 'last_played': 1404400568}
review:
After hours and hours of playing, I've changed my mind. This game is definitely worth $20. It has it's flaws but when compared to Sim City it really does shine in a way that forgives it of it's problems.

=== The GOOD ===
- Real traffic, real pedestrians, and their AI actually calculate's their travel all over the map. You don't have to wait in an area to see the traffic and pedestrians build up. You can zoom into a neighborhood and immediately see all the traffic. The city feels extremely lively. The masses feel real.
- Beautiful game.
- HUGE cities.
- Lots of detail.
- Great frame rate.
- Satisfying.
- Extremely unbalanced. But that's ok because you can use the "Rule Editor" in the Tools menu to change the capacity of all the vehicles, change the break down times, change how fast they are fixed in the repair shops, how many residents the city has, EVERYTHING. So you can re-balance your game however you like. 
- I increased the city population density by 500% and it was awesome! You need to have an extremely good PC because the game calculates each and every person's commute. I increased the capacity of trams to 200 people per tram (more realistic) and 600 people per metro train so it's more realistic and the whole game just got so much more fun. I had 2,000 people waiting at my busiest transit stations. I was so happy. It was everything sim city should have been.

=== The Problems ===
- My game crashes every hour. there's no auto save. But it does not crash on my brothers computer.
- You can't upgrade current roads, you have to bulldoze them and when laying down the new road, if you curve or are off by 1 pixel the buildings around will be destroyed and you can't get them back.
- There's no "undo" option. So if you accidentally destroy a building or are having trouble with rail connections (and you will a lot) you have to bulldoze everything and start over.
- Trams can no longer do U-Turns on avenues like they used to.
- The addition of depots is extremely limiting. ALL buses, metros, trams must start out and end at the same depot. So no more little bus routes.

The team worked really hard on this game, and the assets are top notch. I feel like just 2 more years of development and this game can be fleshed out into a serious Sim City Competitor. If you have problems with the umbalanced gameplay, low vehicle capacity, short break down times, just change the stats in the Rule Editor and game on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014410613', 'num_games_owned': 492, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1601919912}
review:
Got this as part of a humble indie bundle. Looks... interesting. Thought it was a city sim of some sort, but I was wrong. It's a transport sim. It looks slick as hell, and I'm sure if you're the type of person who relishes the idea of meticulously planning bus/train/tram routes, this is probably the game for you!

I wouldn't know if it is really good fun, because the game crashed when another program stole focus. Whereas that is very obviously an implementation flaw, I won't knock the game too much as that wouldn't be a common occurance (I hope).

Anyways, I'm giving it a very shaky recommend: the game itself seems well polished and designed. However, not all people give a damn about maintaing a well planned bus route. Also, the crash when focus lost issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995958437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1551560405}
review:
This game crashes constantly.  I definitely meet the hardware requirements, but that doesn't stop this game from crashing to the desktop every 5 minutes during play.  From what I can tell, this is a problem that the developers have been aware of for 6+ months, but there still isn't a patch or fix for it.  They're probably not planning on fixing this major problem.  Buy at your own risk.

The gameplay is fun (in 5 minute blocks), but from what I can tell, the AI response is also overly simplistic and the commuters don't mind a 6-hour commute.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056870427', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1419524032}
review:
Cities in Motion 2 from my perspective:

I haven't played the first one, only found out about this game late 2012-early 2013 from youtube! Looked up some videos and found it to be quite fun. Basically all you do is enter a city and make a public transportation system in the city so it could expand and make you even more money. To any person that likes or has liked tycoon games this is for you, it is simple and it will keep you entertained for hours of your time. Also it's easy to learn how to play it, but if you want to master all the tricks you might need quite a few hours in the game!

Definitely recommend it to everyone still thinking about buying it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038603906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2600, 'last_played': 1642964407}
review:
Cities in Motion 2 is pretty good. It definitely is true to purpose. It's a satisfying mass-traffic, public transport simulator and management game. I legitimately feel like I should be in an office building wearing a suit while I play this game, which, if you're interested, is probably exactly the kind of thing you're in to.

It has a map editor. It has a rule set editor. Both of these allow you to customize the game surprisingly effectively. I, personally, went through the effort of looking at Google Maps images and remaking my home city and then proceeded to play that map with my friends.

Road building is easy once you get the hang of it. Alternations of click and right-click allow you to customise the shape of your tracks and roads effectively. There is a lot of information available, so there is a bit of getting-used-to time required in order to navigate things correctly, from, for instance, lines to depots to buying vehicles. Timetables are important and there's a lot of micromanaging of vehicles and time required to ensure optimised routes and service. I would recommend starting with a standardised timetable (say, one vehicle every hour) to get the hang of it.

You need to connect to direct IP to get multiplayer to work reliably. Using a VPN such as Hamachi is a good idea for this.

All of the game's issues can be described as annoyances, which is an improvement on game-breaking issues, which many games have these days.
To cut to the chase, the game has the following issues:
- Multiplayer desyncs eventually, meaning eventually you and your friends will have different city economies, income, won't see certain things the others do, etc. You can fix this by manually getting them to replace their save file with yours, which can be tedious. It can take a satisfactory amount of time before this desync happens though, so multiplayer is still functional on a short-medium term basis.
- Many additional vehicles are DLC. It's money grubbing, and it does have some effect on the game, but you don't need the DLC to enjoy the game to the fullest extent unless your enjoyment comes primarily from seeing differently coloured buses and trains. You can modify the game's rules to make your vanilla vehicles have the same or similar functionality to DLC vehicles. No particular loss, just annoying.
- Changing ticket prices can be tedious, but there is a mod to help combat this (available through steam workshop).

If you are reading reviews on this game, you must be interested in some sort of a city management game. This is a public transport management game. It has some city management elements, in that the city's growth is directly affected by the success of your public transport system, but it is mostly a business management game, the business being specifically a public transport system.

I recommend it, you should try it, if you wanted to manage the busses and trains in a SimCity 4-esc city, whilst the city manages itself, and it is very good at doing that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975161393', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1390074483}
review: You play the god of traffic in this non-stop, testosterone fueled, manventure. It starts out in a bustling town in the middle of a larger bustling town, where it becomes your job to create bus lines for the pitiful busless mortals. From there you probably create more buses and roads and theme parks and eventually a road to heaven itself. This game has thrills. It's got spills. And it most likely has the necessary skills to pay the bills. Until you lose interest and quit almost as soon as it's done installing. Recomended.

review: Great trasnportation simulator.  I've wasted hours just playing around in the sandbox alone creating fun and new networks and infrastructure. This games also makes me wish Paradox would take the chance at making a city simulator.  I'd honestly say if this and Simcity had a baby, it'd be my favorite simulator ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966568064', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1389871508}
review:
This game is not for everyone, but is definitely recomended if you like management sims. 

Decent graphics, complex simulation and adequate user interface. It's quite tough in the beginning, but once you get the hang of it and manage to make a decent sized network, it is quite rewarding.

Standard scenario's and maps are alright, but are quite unoriginal in layout and get boring fast. This is definitely not helped by the fact that there are no timeperiods, like the first Cities in Motion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069049840', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1427726165}
review:
very difficult and time consuming. 

if youve never played a game like this before, i suggest you look at gameplay reviews first. 
its alot like simcity... without the city building.

i bought it because i wanted to build my own city but it turned out you build the transport system, not the city. 

like i say its difficult to play at first and you need to have PLENTY of time to play it.

oh and one last thing, if you play sandbox first and tick 'unlimited money' you should get a feel of what the game is like without your money been a worry.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998780075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1450227655}
review:
This game is so bad its frustrating. Generaly just BAD QUALITY in every aspect of the game. The way you build tracks and roads sucks, building underground metro tunnels is the worst. The screen gets filled up with lots of windows everytime you click anything. Route planing is almost as bad as building tracks and gives you no real control, just click some stops and see what happens. There realy should be a way to make "loop-routes" without the bus or whatever unload all passengers and going into the depot at the end of each trip.
Anyway.. I just don't like the gameplay or the interface in the game. What's worse is how buggy the Linux version is. First couple of times I tried to start the game from steam it did just quit at once after it was launched. Had to do som tinkering about and starting the game outside from steam, etc, etc before I could even play the game. It seems to me like most linuxusers doesn't get the water to be rendered. I also discovered that when "painting" ticket zones, all zones (blue, green, red) shows up as yellow in the main window. So you have to look at the minimap and just hope that you can hit the right spot..

Conclussion: There's probably a reason why ther is no demo for this game, nobody would pay money for this after trying it. If you want a transportation game, download OpenTTD instead, it's free and I can't think of any aspect of Cities in Motion that is better than OpenTTD. (If it wasn't so buggy, and the water would render instead of just seeing the bottom of the ocean, MAYBE it would actually look better than OpenTTD.)

Don't buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976314796', 'num_games_owned': 403, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1389716516}
review:
Der zweite Teil ist um einiges Umfangreicher in den Funktionen und Einstellungen, daher brauch es auch mehr Einarbeitung in den Ablauf und deren Funktionen. Die Grafik ist top und stellt sogar das neue SimCity in den Schatten. Ist jedenfalls meine Meinung. Mehr Spaß macht es jedenfalls! Viele Fehler des ersten Teils wurden ausgemerzt und um neue Funktionen erweitert.

Die Kosten für die DLC sind angemessen. Jedenfalls wenn Sie mal wieder im Angebot sind. Die Zusammenstellung der Erweiterungen sind auch fairer gelöst als noch im ersten Teil. Man kann auf jeden Fall eine Menge Spaß mit dem Spiel haben. Die Zeit geht dabei jedenfalls rum wie nix. Sehr kurzweilig.

review: The first game was great, this one is not.  First there are still many issues in the game as well as bugs.  The workshops barely functions for this game (so far I've never had any of the workshop content work properly).  Theres 1 campaign, and sandbox mode. author: {'steamid': '76561198083883063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3492, 'last_played': 1448744097}
review:
This game is a sweet and sour. CiM was somewhat a fun game but lacking a lot in comparisson to Sim City 4 which is the holy grail for this genre. However a lot of these aspects have been improved in the second version of the game. Unfortunately a lot of the aspects have gotten far worse.
Lets start with the city size. What is this? Cities counting 50.000 residents with full on highrise downtown? And of course you have to downgrade the people to this size. So we have mainlines with doubledecker busses carrying 30 people every hour? This is a simulation. And the year is 2014. How is it possible that no one has come as far as SC4 with it's regional play? I mean we have games now as vast and complex as GTA 5. A city sim with that kind of size shouldn't be such a big deal.
The next thing is the DLC. This is the bigggest crime comitted in the world of gaming right now. You pay 20€ for a notreallyalotmorethanashity game like this. Which includes 5 different vehicles. And then you have to buy each new vehicle? for like 1€ each? That's 20€ easily just to get to a diversity of a city with 30 bus lines and a couple of suburban rail lines.
And don't even let me get started on the depots! The busses should not go back to depot after each and every run. Not even trains or trams do that! This concept should be changed!
Oh! Let's also not forget the bugs and bad simulator engine which causes flooding of vehicles on lines and sudenly causes a standstill in your city. Why did I even buy this?

People should really start fighting for their right to a good quality games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119202220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1450560544}

author: {'steamid': '76561198022597328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6268, 'last_played': 1414661896}
review:
Cities in Motion 2 - a disappointing upgrade from the original.

In the Cities in Motion franchise you take control of a public transit company, and attempt to meet the transportation needs of various cities.  You are given specific goals from the City and from other people in the city as 'side quests'.

The campaign mode in CIM2 is very disappointing compared to the first game.  In CIM1, every senario starts in a completely different situation for each city included, and had many tasks to be completed for each one.  So even though you may play in the same city more than once, the situation changes enough to make it interesting.  In CIM2 there are only 5 cities in the campaign, which is not a big problem, except how those cities are used makes it disappointing.  First, each senario typically only has one mail goal, which is usually pretty simple, such as attain a certain level of coverage, or company value growth.  The real problem comes when you return to a city later in the campaign, you are playing in the exact same city you left, with everything you already completed still there ready to go.

There are some good things about this game.  The graphics engine is definitely improved, although the overall user interface is not really improved.  Cities will grow and change over time.  For people who really enjoy micromanagement, you can set very specific schedules for each line you create.  You can also create custom metro trains for each line, however I do wish there was a method to save each custom train for easier purchasing and managing.

The game is still fun to play, but I would only recommend buying it when it is on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068604333', 'num_games_owned': 1194, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 94, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1389431528}
review:
К счастью, игра досталась почти бесплатно, так что о потраченных деньгах не жалею.

"Городской транспорт". Не скрою, эта моя первая стратегия, возможно, из-за этого не понравилось. Честно, я вообще не люблю стратегии на ПК. Я люблю играть стратегии на смартфоне\телефоне, но не на ПК. Слишком сложно, масштабно...

Что не понравилось в этой игре:
- шрифты. После запуска игры еле прочёл вводную информацию, шрифты, мягко говоря, неудачные. Нет сглаживания. 
- очень скучное обучение. Сразу вваливается куча информации на неподготовленного пользователя. И скучная информация.
-первая миссия. "Увеличить покрытие на 15%". Что за покрытие? Дороги, подумал я, но нет. Развить городской транспорт на 15? Скорее всего, построил пару линий автобусов\троллейбусов. Но нет, процент выполнения миссии так и остался на нуле.
- сразу дали целый город. Я не строил этот город, дали уже готовый, огромный.  Ориентироваться очень непросто. Первая миссия должна быть короткой, а не в целом мегаполисе. На мой взгляд.
-неудобное управление. 

Но не всё так плохо, есть плюсы:
-многие ругают игру за плохую графику, но мне так не показалось. Хорошо детализированный город, много разных объектов, приятные текстуры.
-небо. Можно долго разглядывать ночное небо, звёзды, сделано неплохо. Весьма неплохо.
- доступна на ОС Linux. Багов не обнаружено, всё идёт как положено.

Пожалуй, всё. Хорошенько обдумайте, прежде сем покупать данную игру. Возможно, обзор некорректный, так как я не люблю стратегии на ПК. Игра мне не могла понравиться.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048944532', 'num_games_owned': 958, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 21020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18462, 'last_played': 1661693177}
review:
After over 300 hours of gameplay, witnessing the growth of the game and the release of several DLCs. 
I would not recommend this game to anyone, the game is completely abandoned by the developer now and contains a lot of bugs.

it's good if you can tolerate all the faults, such as, but not limited to
- workshop not working
- occasional crash to desktop
- lack of auto-saving
- idiotic AI
- poor map design (of some maps and most workshop maps)
- poor building mechanism
- lack of bug fixes / updates provided by the provider
- lack of comprehensive, interactive tutorials

if you want a stable game / a bug-free game, please play the original Cities in Motion instead of this one,
CiM2 feels rush and not-polished well. The occasional crash to desktop is really annoying

author: {'steamid': '76561198027086818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1388519987}
review: I really liked the idea of this game when I started playing it: you're responsible for building a public transportation system for a metropolis that'd already created for you (cool-looking cities too).  There's an incredible amount of detail for the obsessive and careful, but something as basic and essential as building a bus line is cumbersome, and building a functioning fixed track transport like tram lines is frustrating and overly complicated.  I simply gave up after spending an hour trying to set up one tram line.  The track was always in the wrong place, you can't really drag the cursor to set up a long track line, meaning you have to build them piece by piece.  And then track connections are unreliable, particularly at intersections.  I take for granted in games like this that there's a learning curve and there's tricks you need to learn by trial and error to figure out how to do things, but considering the entire game is building a public transportation system, it should have been made easier.  Not less complex, but easier to execute.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009884241', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1387728269}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973395450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1399260726}
review:
Cities in Motion 2 (CM2) is published by Paradox, so that should tell you three things: first, it has a steep learning curve; second, it has a horrific UI and mind-boggling design decisions; and third, it will take something mundane and make it addictive. CM2 really has a problem with the second of these. For example, the victory conditions of the campaign maps are "Have x% coverage". Unfortunately for the player, "coverage" means nothing like the English word "coverage," and its precise meaning is never explained. This makes the game artificially difficult. Despite these gripes, the game still is entertaining.

While entertaining, and definitely worth the $5 I paid for it, I can't bring myself to recommend this game. This is due in part to the designer's attitude towards DLC ($5 for more busses?) and how its patches focus on niche markets (Mac-only issues, Linux compatibility) despite persistent and well-documented bugs that affect everyone.

TL;DR: Engaging and entertaining, yet buggy, has awful UI, and is worse than an EA game for DLC.

review: Great game. People have complained how it was so different from CIM 1 and thats true but it is a different good. They just need more DLC and another transit mode or two and it would be great. Colossal Order is a great company yet small. They are very flexible and open and this game has more potential then it is now it could with some more publicity and minor improvements could get some people from the city builder market as well. This game would not replace Simcity or Cities XL but add another fun game to the libary for those people and aid them in their city building games. I play SImcity and my city runs so smothly thanks to some ideas from CIM2. Great game buy it. Ignore some of the not reccommended people out there they likely wanted it to be like CIM 1. If so thats fine buy and play CIM 1 and the people who like CIM 2 will buy and play that one. Great job Colossal Order

review: I've played thousands of hours of Transport Tycoon and I thought this would be similar, but it's been a huge disappointment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009068164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1336, 'last_played': 1390104340}
review:
Cities in Motion 2 is a well made game. The city grows dynamically with night/day cycle but no weather.
You're in charge to develop and maintain the various cities public transportation. In game this includes: Buses, Trams, Trolleys (Busses with overhead electric lines), boats, and trains(metro which includes subway). Each individual in the game's world is given a category among others: pensioner, businessman, student, tourist, white collar worker and blue collar worker. Each of these categories has their own public transportation preferences and different service level expectancies. So you try to cater for their different needs while trying to make the company profitable to further expand your services. All in all it's quite a detailed game. The learning curve can be a little bit daunting at first but highly rewarding once everything has been figured out. Attention to details and thoughtful design (the head developer was a female so attention to details and thoughtfulness are superb) made this game an enjoyable one to play especially online in cooperation mode. Highly recommended for family LAN game party. This is one of those games that has a little bit education in it for your children while still being genuinely fun to play for an adult.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009002809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1389289151}
review:
Hidastempoinen strategiapeli, jossa tarkoituksena on luoda kaupungin julkinen liikennejärjestelmä ja tehdä sillä rahaa. Rakentaminen on helppoa tehdä muutamassa tunnissa, mutta suurin osa ajasta kuluukin säätämiseen. Pelin käytettävyys ei ole huippuluokkaa ja esimerkiksi yksittäisen pysäkin lisääminen reitille onnistuu vain poistamalla koko reitti käytöstä, poistamalla kaikki tämän pysäkin jälkeen tulevat pysäkit reitiltä ja tekemällä kaikki tämä työ uudestaan.

Peli on kuitenkin hyvä lähtökohta sille, mitä pelisarja voi myöhemmin olla. Jos käytettävyyttä hiotaan seuraavassa osassa, voi sille jo antaa varauksettoman suosituksen hidastempoisista strategiarakenteluista pitäville, mutta tällä hetkellä pelin toinen osa kannattaa ostaa vain tarjouksesta ja vain pitkäpinnaisen pelattavaksi.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995940728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 26053, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5814, 'last_played': 1527837017}
review:
Well-made game that plays smoothly and feels well-optimized. Complaints include
-Sometimes roads can't be placed or deleted without good reason, and you'll have to work around this in your construction.
-The AI cars are pretty good but are bad at making full use of multi-lane roads and merging, which can lead to unnecesary and unrealistic congestion.
-Content is a little stingy, nowhere near Train Simulator Level, but factor in paying a $10-20 more in DLCs.
However this game is a niche genre and apart from some minor things is very well made and fun to play if you'd be into this sort of game.
-No Mods, dunno if they're not supported or people just don't feel like making em'

Positives include
+Great interface for moving the camera around and constructng things
+Good optimization, Only ever noticed fps drops on a ridiculously-complex map of Bangkok(Which was totally smooth after lowering some settings), my computer is fairly powerful(Intel Core 2 Quad Q9550 + Ati 7850) though.
+Community maps out the ass, thanks to useful tool that converts real world openstreetmaps into game maps
+Game Devs give A-OK for monetized youtube footage of their game, and even wrote up a letter for people to send to youtube.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051486413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1373096112}
review: While this game is fun and reminds me of Transport Tycoon, it has one major flow which turned me off from this game. The economy fluctuates like crazy and by crazy every few minutes (game time). For example, one minute a ticket price of $0.40 is acceptable (blue) and another extremly unacceptable (red). The devs are aware of this issue and won't spend time to fix it and instead focus on bumping more DLCs out (see forums).

The cities and mechanics are completley different and you have to use WASD keys to move around instead of using the old mouse on the edge of the screen move. I'm pretty disaapointed with this. author: {'steamid': '76561198004924505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 10848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10261, 'last_played': 1688241813}
review:
Gelungener Nachfolger von Cities in Motion 1. Anfangs muss man sich allerdings an ein paar Änderungen im Linienmanagement gewöhnen, aber dann hat es durchaus seinen Reiz, an den Fahrplänen zu tüfteln. Die Unterschiede zu CiM 1 sind dabei deutlich genug, dass ich auch beide Spiele weiterhin spiele.
Die größte Stärke von CiM 2 ist meiner Meinung nach aber der stark verbesserte Karteneditor. Hier lassen sich relativ schnell große Städte erstellen. Erst die Landschaft etwas formen mit Hügeln, Wasserläufen, Wäldern, etc., dann die gewünschten Straßenläufe bauen. Die Gebäude werden dann per Knopfdruck an diesen Straßen generiert. Sie müssen nicht wie beim Vorgänger einzeln von Hand gesetzt werden - können sie aber, wenn man an bestimmten Stellen unbedingt bestimmte Gebäude haben will. Etwas störend ist derzeit auch ein Bug mit Karten aus dem  Workshop, deren Höhen-Informationen mitunter nicht geladen werden. Aber es gibt auch Alternativen zum Mapaustausch.
Etwas nachteilig mag noch die geringe Auswahl an Fahrzeugen erscheinen (pro Transportmittel ein kleines, mittleres und großes Fahrzeug), die sich nur durch die DLCs erweitern lässt.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197976751797', 'num_games_owned': 455, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1387501403}
review:
Das Spiel ist echt ganz gut gelungen. Ich finde es sehr gut, dass man auch endlich selbst Straßen bauen kann, da man so nicht mehr an Kartenvorgaben gebunden ist. Man hat eine gute Übersicht über das Spielgeschehen und die Grafik macht echt was her. Auch hat man viele kleine Möglichkeiten seine Routen zu optimieren, Fahrpläne zu kreieren, sogar die Spuren auf der Straße sind auswählbar zur Benutzung. Trotzdem gibt es auch einige Punkte die ich bemänglen muss. Die KI ist nicht immer gut drauf, so dass es hier und da mal dazu kommen kann, dass man eine Route umlegen muss, da ansonsten an einer Kreuzung Fahrzeuge sich gegenüberstehen und sich gegenseitig die Vorfahrt zuschieben ;) Auch die Einstellungen für Fahrpreise und Gehälter sind nicht ganz klar. Es gibt teilweise recht starke Schwankungen ...
Alles in allem würde ich das Spiel aber empfehlen. Hat bisher sehr viel Spaß gemacht :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198012654954', 'num_games_owned': 2782, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1388224792}
review:
